an3.36:4.1: “There are, mendicants, these three messengers of the gods.
an3.36:4.3: Firstly, someone does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an3.36:4.4: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an3.36:4.5: Then the wardens of hell take them by the arms and present them to King Yama, saying:
an3.36:4.6: ‘Your Majesty, this person did not pay due respect to their mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, or honor the elders in the family.
an3.36:5.1: Then King Yama questions, presses, and examines them about the first messenger of the gods.
an3.36:5.2: ‘Mister, did you not see the first messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’
an3.36:6.2: ‘Mister, did you not see among human beings an elderly woman or a man—eighty, ninety, or a hundred years old—bent double, crooked, leaning on a stick, trembling as they walk, ailing, past their prime, with teeth broken, hair grey and scanty or bald, skin wrinkled, and limbs blotchy?’
an3.36:7.2: ‘Mister, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—
an3.36:7.3: “It is my nature, too, to age. I’m not exempt from ageing. I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’
an3.36:8.2: ‘Mister, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.
an3.36:8.3: Well, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.
an3.36:8.4: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by the gods, or by ascetics and brahmins.
an3.36:8.5: That bad deed was done by you alone, and you alone will experience the result.’
an3.36:9.1: Then King Yama questions them about the second messenger of the gods.
an3.36:9.2: ‘Mister, did you not see the second messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’
an3.36:9.6: ‘Mister, did you not see among human beings a woman or a man, sick, suffering, gravely ill, collapsed in their own urine and excrement, being picked up by some and put down by others?’
an3.36:10.2: ‘Mister, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—
an3.36:10.3: “It is my nature, too, to become sick. I’m not exempt from sickness. I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’
an3.36:11.2: ‘Mister, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.
an3.36:11.3: Well, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.
an3.36:11.4: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by the gods, or by ascetics and brahmins.
an3.36:11.5: That bad deed was done by you alone,
an3.36:11.6: and you alone will experience the result.’
an3.36:12.1: Then King Yama questions them about the third messenger of the gods.
an3.36:12.2: ‘Mister, did you not see the third messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’
an3.36:13.2: ‘Mister, did you not see among human beings a woman or a man, dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering?’
an3.36:14.2: ‘Mister, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—
an3.36:14.3: “It is my nature, too, to die. I’m not exempt from death. I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’
an3.36:15.2: ‘Mister, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.
an3.36:15.3: Well, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.
an3.36:15.4: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by the gods, or by ascetics and brahmins.
an3.36:15.5: That bad deed was done by you alone,
an3.36:15.6: and you alone will experience the result.’
an3.36:16.1: Then, after questioning them about the third messenger of the gods, King Yama falls silent.
an3.36:16.2: Then the wardens of hell punish them with the five-fold crucifixion.
an3.36:16.3: They drive red-hot stakes through the hands and feet, and another in the middle of the chest.
an3.36:16.8: And there they feel painful, intense, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.
an3.36:17.1: Then the wardens of hell thrown them down and hack them with axes.
an3.36:17.2: And there they feel painful, intense, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.
an3.36:18.1: Then the wardens of hell hang them upside-down and hack them with hatchets.
an3.36:18.2: Then the guards of hell harness them to a chariot, and drive them back and forth across burning ground, blazing and glowing.
an3.36:18.3: Then the guards of hell make him climb up and down a huge mountain of burning coals, blazing and glowing.
an3.36:18.4: Then the guards of hell turn them upside down and throw them in a red-hot copper pot, burning, blazing, and glowing.
an3.36:18.5: There they’re seared in boiling scum, and they’re swept up and down and round and round.
an3.36:18.6: And there they feel painful, intense, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.
an3.36:18.7: Then the guards of hell toss them in the Great Hell.
an3.36:19.1: ‘Four are its corners, four its doors,
an3.36:20.1: The ground is even made of iron,
an3.36:21.1: Once upon a time, King Yama thought:
an3.36:21.2: ‘Those who do such bad deeds in the world receive these many different punishments.
an3.36:21.3: Oh, I wish that I get reborn as a human being! And that a Realized One—a Perfect One, a fully awakened Buddha—arises in the world! And that I can pay homage to the Buddha!
an3.36:21.4: Then the Buddha can teach me Dharma, so that I can understand his teaching.’
an3.36:21.5: Now, I don’t say this because I’ve heard it from some other ascetic or brahmin. I only say it because I’ve known, seen, and realized it for myself.”
